questions.text: 60 years old male patient was brought to emergency department after history of sudden collapse. The doctor took pulse of the common carotid artery in the neck and declared him dead. Against which vertebrae doctor palpated the artery?
questions.solution:
Common carotid artery:

  • The common carotid arise from
    • Right side: branch of brachiocephalic trunk
    • Left side: branch of arch of aorta.
  • At the level of the upper border of the thyroid cartilage, the artery ends by dividing into the external and internal carotid arteries.
  • The pulsation of common carotid artery can be felt by compressing against the carotid tubercle, i.e. the anterior tubercle of the transverse process of vertebra C6 (Option C) which lies at the level of the cricoid cartilage.
  • Carotid tubercle is also known as chassaignac's tubercle.
  • So Options A, B, D are wrong.

Vertebral level of other structures in the neck as follow:

Tag: Deep structures of the neck

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 91

questions.text: 30 years male had an injury at the marked structure in the figure. Which of the following structure might be injured in that patient?
questions.solution:
Marked structure is pterion:

  • The anterior part of the floor of temporal fossa is crossed by an H shaped suture where four bones-frontal, parietal, greater wing of sphenoid and temporal adjoin each other.
  • This area is termed the pterion.
  • Structures related to pterion are:
    1. Anterior branch of middle meningeal artery
    2. Sylvia's fissure(lateral fissure of cerebral hemisphere)
    3. Sphenoid fontanelle
    4. Insula
    5. Brocas area
  • In roadside accidents, the anterior division of middle meningeal artery (Option A) at Pterion may be ruptured, leading to clot formation between the skull bone and dura mater or Extradural haemorrhage.
  • Lucid interval is characteristic of EDH, but can also be present in SDH
  • Structure given in (Options B, C, D) are not related to pterion.

Tag: The skull bone

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 19, 20

questions.text: 40 years male patient visited OPD with complaint of loss of taste sensation from the marked area in the given figure below. Which of the following nerve carries taste sensation from the affected area?
questions.solution:
Sensory supply of tongue:

Motor supply of tongue:

  • All muscles of tongue are supplied by hypoglossal nerve (Option C) except Palatoglossus that is supplied by vago accessory complex.

Tag: The tongue

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number – 190

choices.text: Great auricular nerve and posterior auricular nerve
Lesser auricular nerve and auriculotemporal nerve

questions.text: A 30 year old male had undergone parotid surgery. After few days he came to OPD with complaint of redness and pain with perspiration around ear when he eats something. Which of the following nerves may be involved in the patient?
questions.solution:
Frey’s syndrome (auriculotemporal nerve syndrome):

  • Sometimes penetrating wounds of the parotid gland may damage auriculotemporal and great auricular nerves (Option A).
    • So other options (B, C, D) are wrong.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve contains parasympathetic (secretomotor), sensory, and sympathetic fibres.
  • The great auricular nerve contains sensory and sudomotor fibres.
  • When these nerves are cut, during regeneration the secretomotor fibres (auriculotemporal fibres) grow into endoneurial sheaths of fibres (greater auricular fibres) supplying cutaneous receptors for pain, touch and temperature, and sympathetic fibres supplying sweat glands and blood vessels.
  • Thus a stimulus intended for salivation evokes cutaneous hyperesthesia, sweating, and flushing.
  • The presenting features of Frey’s syndrome are:
    • When a person eats, the ipsilateral cheek (parotid region) becomes red, hot, and painful. It is associated with beads of perspiration (gustatory sweating).
    • When a person shaves, there is cutaneous hyperesthesia in front of the ear.

Tag: Parotid region

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 115

questions.text: Whitnall's tubercle present in which of the following part of the orbit?
questions.solution:
Boundaries of walls of orbit:

  • Medial wall (Option C): thinnest wall of orbit
    • uSMLE(pneumonic)- Sphenoid,Maxilla,Lacrimal, Ethmoidal bone
  • Lateral wall (Option D):
    • Greater wing of sphenoid bone
    • Zygomatic bone
    • Whitnall's tubercle, a small bony tubercle just behind the lateral orbital margin and slightly below the frontozygomatic suture.
  • Floor (Option B): commonest site for fracture of orbital wall(BLOW OUT FRACTURE)
    • Maxilla
    • Zygomatic bone
    • Palatine bone
  • Roof (Option A):
    • Frontal bone
    • Lesser wing of sphenoid(OPTIC CANAL is present in the lesser wing of sphenoid).
  • Apex:
    • It is formed by the centre of the bony bridge between optic canal and superior orbital fissure.

Tag: The orbit

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 273 to 275

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient was diagnosed with crocodile tear syndrome. At which of the following level the facial nerve may be injured?
questions.solution:
Injuries of facial nerve:

KEY TAKEAWAYS - BELL'S PALSY :

  • Acute onset LMN palsy
  • m/c cause IDIOPATHIC > viral (HSV-1)
  • m/c site of involvement - labyrinthine segment
  • Treatment - high dose steroid (immediately), anti viral (acyclovir), vit b12 supplements

Note: crocodile tears/synkinesis - aberrant regeneration of FACIAL NERVE

Freys syndrome/ gustatory sweating -AURICULOTEMPORAL nerve injured

Tag: Deep structures of the neck

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number – 331, 332

questions.text: Which of the following is the safety muscle of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Safety muscles of larynx:

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the only intrinsic muscles of the larynx, which abduct the vocal cords to allow entry of air through rima glottidis in the respiratory tract below it.
  • If posterior cricoarytenoids are paralyzed, the adductor muscles (of vocal cords) take the upper hand and the person might die due to lack of air.
  • Hence the posterior circoarytenoid muscles (Option B) are called safety muscles of the larynx.

Option A, C, D are adductors of vocal cords

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Safety muscle of larynx- posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue - genioglossus

Safety muscle of mandible(mouth opening) - lateral pterygoid

Tag: Larynx

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 217, 219

questions.text: All of the followings are the branches of first part of the maxillary artery, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Maxillary artery:

  • The maxillary artery is the larger terminal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • It arises behind the neck of the mandible, runs horizontally forward up to the lower border of lower head of lateral pterygoid,
  • The maxillary artery is divided into three parts by the lower head of lateral pterygoid muscle.

Branches of maxillary artery:

Option B, C, D are branches from 1st part of maxillary artery

Option A - is branch from 3rd part of maxillary artery


Tag: Infratemporal fossa

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 135, 137

questions.text: Secretomotor fibers of the submandibular gland are derived from which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Secretomotor supply of glands of head and neck:

  • Parotid gland:
    • It is provided through auriculotemporal nerve.
    • The preganglionic fibers - arise from the inferior salivatory nucleus in the medulla and pass successively through glossopharyngeal nerve, tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal (Jacobson’s nerve), tympanic plexus and lesser petrosal nerve to relay into otic ganglion.
    • Postganglionic fibers  - arise from the cells of the ganglion and pass through the auriculotemporal nerve to supply the parotid gland.
    • The stimulation of parasympathetic supply produces watery secretion.
  • Submandibular gland:
    • The preganglionic parasympathetic fibers - arise from superior salivatory nucleus in the pons and pass successively through facial nerve, chorda tympani, and lingual nerves; and terminate in the submandibular ganglion, which serves as a relay station.
    • The postganglionic fibers - arise from this ganglion and directly supply the submandibular gland.
    • So it is supplied by facial nerve (Option A).
  • sublingual gland:
    • It is similar to that of submandibular salivary gland.
  • Lacrimal gland:
    • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers - Arise from lacrimatory nucleus in the pons and pass successively through nervus intermedius, geniculate ganglion, greater petrosal nerve, nerve of pterygoid canal to reach the pterygopalatine ganglion where they relay.
    • The postganglionic fibers - arise from the cells of the pterygopalatine ganglion and pass successively through maxillary nerve, zygomatic nerve, zygomaticotemporal nerve and lacrimal nerve to reach the lacrimal gland.

Tag: Glands of head and neck

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 65, 115, 126, 127

questions.text: Cranial part accessory nerve supplies all the muscles palate, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Muscles of palate:

  • The soft palate consists of the five pairs of muscles.
    • Muscles supplied by pharyngeal plexus:
      • Levator veli palatini (Option D)
      • Palatoglossus (Option A)
      • Palatopharyngeus
      • Musculus uvulae (Option B)
    • Muscles supplied by mandibular nerve:
      • Tensor veli palatini (Option C)

Distribution of cranial part of 11th cranial nerve:

  • The pharyngeal branch of vagus nerve arises from the lower part of the inferior ganglion of the vagus, and contains chiefly the fibres of the cranial root of accessory nerve.
  • It passes between the external and internal carotid arteries, and reaches the upper border of the middle constrictor of the pharynx where it takes part in forming the pharyngeal plexus.
  • The cranial root of the accessory nerve via the vagus nerve and pharyngeal plexus of nerves supplies:
    • All the muscles of the palate except the tensor palatini and tensor tympani which are supplied by the mandibular nerve (nerve to medial pterygoid).
    • All the muscles of the pharynx except stylopharyngeus which is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Tag: The larynx

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 210, 338

questions.text: 40 years old male patient undergone with thyroidectomy. Which of the following nerves are commonly injuried during surgery?
questions.solution:
Thyroidectomy:

  • Removal of the thyroid (thyroidectomy) with true capsule may be necessary in hyperthyroidism.
  • External and recurrent laryngeal nerves (Option C) are most commonly injured during surgery.
  • The superior thyroid artery and the external laryngeal nerve diverge from each other near the apex.
  • The artery lies superficial and the nerve lies deep to the apex.
  • Therefore, during thyroidectomy, the superior thyroid artery should be ligated as close to the apex of thyroid lobe as possible to avoid injury to the external laryngeal nerve.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve lies very close to the inferior thyroid artery near the base of the thyroid lobe.
  • But now both superior and inferior thyroid artery should be ligated close to the gland , so that parathyroid glands are spared

KEY TAKEAWAYS -

m\c nerve injured in thyroid surgery - external laryngeal nerve > recurrent laryngeal nerve , so indirect laryngoscopy to be done preoperatively , so that vocal cords are normal before surgery .

Both superior and inferior thyroid artery is ligated as close to base of gland possible

Tag: The larynx

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4thEdition, Page Number – 159

questions.text: Which of the following ligament of the atlantoaxial joint is remnant of the notochord?
questions.solution:
Atlantoaxial joints:

  • Three well-separated joints are formed between the atlas and the axis, viz.
  • Median atlantoaxial joint.
  • Two lateral atlantoaxial joints.

Ligaments atlantoaxial joints:

  • Apical ligament of the dens (Option A):
    • It extends from tip of odontoid process to the upper surface of the basilar part of the occipital bone near the foramen magnum.
    • Morphologically it represents the remnant of the notochord (cf. Nucleus pulposus).
  • Alar ligaments (Option B):
    • One on each side, extend from the upper part of the dens (on side of the tip) to the tubercle on the medial aspect of the occipital condyle.
  • Membrana tectoria (Option C):
    • It is an upward continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Cruciform (transverse) ligament (option D):
    • It is attached on each side to the medial surface of the lateral mass of the atlas.
    • In the median plane its fibres are prolonged, upwards to the basiocciput and downwards to the body of the axis.
    • Thus forming the cruciform ligament of the atlas

Tag: Joints of neck

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4thEdition, Page Number - 106, 107

choices.text: It forms pully to bind digastric tendon

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the investing layer of deep cervical fascia, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The investing layer of deep cervical fascia:

  • It lies deep to the platysma, and surrounds the neck like a collar.
  • It forms the roof of the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck
  • Features: RULE OF 2 : it encloses
    • trapezius and sternocleidomastoid (Option C)
    • parotid and submandibular glands. So (Option B) is incorrect.
    • suprasternal and supraclavicular spaces.
    • pulleys to bind the tendons of the digastric and omohyoid muscles (Option D).
    • roof of anterior and posterior triangles.
    • stylomandibular ligament and parotidomasseteric fascia (option A).

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4thEdition, Page Number – 73

choices.text: Right superior rectus and left inferior oblique
Right superior rectus and left superior oblique
Right inferior oblique and left superior rectus
Right superior oblique and left superior rectus

questions.text: Figure is showing the normal eye looking forward and other movement of eyeball. Which of the following muscles is involved in the movement shown in the figure below?
questions.solution:
• Normally, movements of the two eyes are harmoniously coordinated.
  • Such coordinated movements of both eyes are called conjugate ocular movements.
  • Conjugate ocular movements with muscle involved in it are shown in the figure below.
  • So (Option C) is a correct answer for the movement asked in the figure.

Tag: The orbit and eyeball

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number – 233, 234

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of stapedius nerve?
questions.solution:
Stapedius is supplied by facial nerve:

  • Origin:
    • pyramidal eminence on the posterior wall of tympanic cavity.
  • Insertion:
    • Posterior aspect of the neck of stapes.
  • Nerve supply:
    • Stapedial branch of facial nerve (Option A).
  • Action:
    • Draws the stapes laterally thus tilting its footplate in the oval window.
  • Applied aspect:
    • Hyperacusis: Both, tensor tympani and stapedius contract reflexly and simultaneously to dampen very loud sounds, thus preventing noise trauma to the internal ear.
    • The paralysis of stapedius results in hyperacusis (an abnormally increased power of hearing) where even whisper appears as noise.

Tag: The ear

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4thEdition, Page Number – 265
